text:
Two questions:
• Does anyone know a Julia package for point processes? Is there a need for one?
• Is there a Julia package more general than `Distributions.jl`, in which the sample can have an arbitrary type?
Context: I’m trying to apply HMMs with point process emissions. I recoded some point processes and the Baum-Welch algorithm, but I would like to make my code available. I like the concept behind <https://github.com/maxmouchet/HMMBase.jl>, which contains distribution-independent inference and learning algorithms. Only problem is: `Distributions.jl`  only supports reals or arrays as sample types, and the observations in my case are point process histories

text: Regarding the second question, <@U81PB6N77> has been doing a lot of work on MeasureTheory.jl. I wonder if MeasureTheory.jl can handle your use case.

elements.text: has been doing a lot of work on MeasureTheory.jl. I wonder if MeasureTheory.jl can handle your use case.

text: But it's probably irrelevant to your problem :sweat_smile:

elements.text: But it's probably irrelevant to your problem

text: <https://github.com/mschauer/Mitosis.jl> will give a common interface to hidden markov models, currently the Gaussian case and the SDE and the finite state space Markov chain are developed, but Markov jump processes will follow

elements.text: will give a common interface to hidden markov models, currently the Gaussian case and the SDE and the finite state space Markov chain are developed, but Markov jump processes will follow

text: It would be interesting to see you code to figure out how it would “fit”

elements.text: It would be interesting to see you code to figure out how it would “fit”

text: Yes, we'd love to have this sort of thing in MeasureTheory.jl. What representation are you using for point process histories?
